Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support undergraduate participants of the Texas Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (TUMC) which will be hosted on November 2-3, 2018 by Stephen F. Austin State University in Nacogdoches, Texas. In fall 2019, TUMC will be hosted by the University of Texas at Tyler. The conference focus is on research done by undergraduate students or in conjunction with undergraduates. This conference offers undergraduates the opportunity to see the research being done by their peers and to start the transition into the larger community of mathematical research.

Now in its 15th year, the Texas Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (TUMC) seeks to provide students with a forum to present their work, to discover research opportunities, and to learn more about graduate school and non-academic careers in mathematics. Conference attendees often come from groups that are underrepresented at research conferences: TUMC recruits many students from community colleges, Hispanic serving institutions, historically black colleges and universities, and institutions having at least 40% first generation college students. As part of this vital link between underserved undergraduate students and the mathematical research community, TUMC will be run without any associated cost for undergraduate participants. This support is meant to increase participation from institutions with limited resources, such as community colleges. The Executive Committee for TUMC will also expand their efforts in collecting demographic information to include information about the research activities of student and faculty participants. In particular, they will investigate the ways in which the uptake of research activities occurs in the year after attending TUMC. Additional information about the conference can be found on the website: http://sections.maa.org/texas/tumc/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On November 2nd and 3rd of 2018, Stephen F. Austin State University (SFA) hosted the Texas Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (TUMC) with approximately 250 participants. This was significantly more participants than the last time TUMC was held in Nacogdoches and the largest number of attendees in the fifteen years TUMC has been held. This conference consisted of 45 student research talks, two short faculty talks, two invited addresses, and two breakout sessions for roundtable discussions. This conference served as a vital resource in undergraduate researchers presenting their work and engaging a wider group of students and faculty in the mathematical sciences. 

The survey given 6 months after the conference had 62 anonymous respondents. Self-reported demographic variables (such as Student/Faculty, Class Standing, Race, etc. as self-reported) were collected in the conference registration and the 6-month survey and these variables showed that the survey respondent sample was broadly representative of the conference participants as a whole. More than two thirds of the student respondents describe ways in which their engagement in undergraduate research increased (began informal work with a faculty member, began work on a formal project, applied to an REU, etc.). About 60% of the faculty respondents reported an increase in undergraduate research activities. When asked “Which activity at TUMC did you feel had the most impact in encouraging and enabling you to increase your activity in research?” participant responses mentioned all aspects of the conference with around half of respondents citing the Student talks as the most impactful. When asked “Which activity at TUMC did you feel could be improved to be more useful to students?”, respondents cited Breakout Sessions that were not applicable to them or the want for more Informal Meeting times. The open ended comments on the survey were overwhelmingly complementary.

Texas Section NExT (New Experiences in Teaching) fellows met at TUMC 2018 and participated in sessions specifically designed for them including “Making Great Teaching/Learning Materials” and relating this to the fellows’ teaching goals. The fellows also had additional meeting time with the invited speakers and other visitors including during Saturday lunch. Around 25 faculty members participated in some aspects of the Texas Section NExT sessions.
